title: Billy Cann
text:
Wiliam A. Cann (1882–1958) was an Australian <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1900s who later wrote for "<a href="The%20Sydney%20Morning%20Herald">The Sydney Morning Herald</a>". A <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales state</a> and <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia national</a> representative <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Loose%20forward%20/%20Lock%20forward">lock forward</a>, he has been named as one of the nation's finest footballers of the 20th century. Cann played his club football for <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney</a> with whom he won the <a href="1914%20NSWRFL%20Premiership">1914 NSWRFL Premiership</a>. In 1907 he played for <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> in the very first rugby match run by the newly created '<a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League">New South Wales Rugby Football League</a>' which had just split away from the established <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">New South Wales Rugby Football Union</a>. Cann was also a long-term administrator at Souths and a football journalist.
Playing career.
Cann, a contemporary of <a href="Dally%20Messenger">Dally Messenger</a> and <a href="Albert%20Rosenfeld">Albert Rosenfeld</a>, began his playing career as a <a href="Rugby%20union">Rugby union</a> three-quarter at Souths. Frustrated at being ignored by rugby union selectors, he joined the rebel <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales rugby league team</a> which played the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team%23The%20All%20Golds">New Zealand All Golds</a> in 1907. Cann joined <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a> in 1908. Cann was also selected to play for <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales</a> in their first ever rugby league game against Queensland, scoring a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the 43–0 victory, which was the first in a clean sweep of all three of the <a href="1908%20interstate%20series">1908 interstate series</a>' games. Butler was then selected to tour England with the <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Kangaroos</a> in the <a href="1908%E2%80%9309%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain">1908–09</a> so was unable to play in Souths' <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%201908%23Final">first premiership win</a> in 1908. Cann is listed on the Australian Players Register as Kangaroo No. 20. Cann was a member of the premiership-winning Souths teams of <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%201909%23Finals">1909</a>. As Canns family history is now lost forever
Cann also represented <a href="Australasia%20rugby%20league%20team">Australasia</a> in 1910. Cann was selected to go on the <a href="1911%E2%80%9312%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain">1911–12 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain</a> as well as two tours to New Zealand with the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales team</a>. Cann was a member of the premiership-winning Souths teams of <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%201914">1914</a>. He had played 9 seasons with the club.
Administrative career.
Cann was a member of Souths' committee from 1908 as well as a delegate to the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20Football%20League">New South Wales Rugby Football League</a> (NSWRFL). In 1921–1922, Cann was co-manager of the <a href="Kangaroo%20tour">Kangaroo tour</a> along with Souths' secretary, <a href="S.%20G.%20%26quot%3BGeorge%26quot%3B%20Ball">S. G. "George" Ball</a>.
During the 1940s and 1950s, Cann was a vice-president of the <a href="NSWRFL">NSWRFL</a>. He also wrote for "<a href="The%20Sydney%20Morning%20Herald">The Sydney Morning Herald</a>".
Accolades.
Cann is credited with shaping the role of the lock in the new code. John Quinlan (1911–1912 tour co-manager) said of Cann: "It was he who introduced the typical Australian style of fast forward play in which the backs and forwards combine so effectively and spectacularly. It is no reflection on his successors to say the original model remains the greatest gem."
He was awarded Life Membership of the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Rugby%20League">New South Wales Rugby League</a> in 1914.
In February 2008, Cann was named in the list of Australia's <a href="List%20of%20Australian%20rugby%20league%27s%20100%20greatest%20players">"100 Greatest Players"</a> (1908–2007) which was commissioned by the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> and <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">ARL</a> to celebrate the code's centenary year in Australia.
